title: Narrative progression in the short story
abstractText: This project attempts a description of some of the core language-based means by which different kinds of narrative progression are engendered in the reader. A combination of corpus analysis and reader-response testing is used to support an account of how such fundamental elements of narratively as (reader perception of) suspense, surprise, secrets and gaps created in representative short stories.
impactText: In my published book of 2009, and in testing and discussion of the ideas presented in that book, by scholars and graduate students in stylistics and narrative studies. Education Cultural
findingsText: I have proposed and discussed and begun the testing of some of the central linguistic resources that I argue guide readers' expectations as they process complex literary narratives. by taking separately each of my proposed 'drivers' of narrative expectation, and using psycholinguistic and reader-response methods to probe the importance of each 'driver' to reader's understanding of the story Creative Economy,Education
